column2: Master of Science in Accounting
column38: School of Business
column47: The Master of Science in Accounting (MS in Accounting) is a 30-credit graduate program designed for individuals who wish to develop the skills and knowledge necessary to pursue a career in public accounting, and meet the 150-credit hour licensure requirement in New York State. The graduate program also serves as a foundation for doctoral studies and other business-related professional careers.
column50: Our undergraduate and graduate programs are accredited by AACSB International-the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business. Less than five percent of business schools worldwide have earned this distinction.

column2: Adapted Physical Education (Advanced Certificate)
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column47: The Advanced Certificate in Adapted Physical Education is a 15-credit program of study that results in a recommendation for New York State certification as a teacher of adapted physical education. The program is specifically designed to meet the academic requirements for the New York State certification exam in adapted/special physical education. The program is offered fully online. This program is designed for individuals who have already earned initial or professional NYS certification in physical education and have completed a master's degree. The courses focus on developing knowledge and skills in the areas of assessment, instruction, and consultation as they pertain to teaching physical education to students with disabilities.
column52: $471 per credit for NYS residents, $963 per credit for out-of-state students

column2: Master of Science in Education in Adolescence Education: Biology
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column47: The Master of Science in Education in Adolescence Education program is a 36-39 credit graduate program that prepares students for initial and/or professional certification as a secondary classroom teacher in New York State. This program is for students who do not have a teaching certification. Program concentrations are available for the following content areas: biology, chemistry, earth science, English, French, mathematics, physics, social studies and Spanish. This program leads to an MSEd degree and eligibility for New York State Initial Teacher Certification in Adolescence Education, grades 7-12, in the student’s academic specialty. An option for dual certification in TESOL or Students with Disabilities is also available. Successful completion of the program and passing of all required New York State certification examinations (EAS, edTPA, and appropriate CST) will lead to the College’s recommendation for the Initial Certificate.
column50: Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP)

column2: Adolescence Education: Biology + Students with Disabilities Certification (Advanced Certificate)
column16:
A bachelor’s degree in one of the content areas (or the equivalent of 30 credits in the content area), with a GPA of 3.0 or higher.
Initial Teacher Certification in the same content area.
Online application
Official transcripts from all colleges/universities attended
Two letters of recommendation (one academic, one professional)
A statement of objectives
A resume
Proof of fingerprint clearance
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column47: Our Adolescence Inclusive Generalist Education programs lead to dual certification in the student’s content area and Students with Disabilities Generalist (7-12). The program is for students who have already earned an undergraduate degree in one of the content areas listed below. Our programs are nationally recognized by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP). We are also proud to have a very high employment rate for our graduates.
column50: The Teacher Education programs at SUNY Brockport are accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).

column2: Master of Science in Education in Adolescence Education: Biology + Students with Disabilities Certification
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column47: Are you a problem-solver? A mentor? A leader? Do you want to work with adolescents of all abilities? Our adolescence inclusive general-ed program is for you. This program leads to dual certification in your content area (grades 7-12) and as a Teacher of Students with Disabilities (grades 7-12). Our program is committed to preparing teachers to meet the needs of all learners in today's diverse classrooms. Students will engage in coursework that focuses on content-specific pedagogy and inclusive practices, including co-teaching and collaboration, differentiating instruction, and culturally responsive-sustaining education. Through a series of carefully planned field experiences, students will have the opportunity to implement what they have learned with the mentorship of our expert faculty.
column50: The educator preparation programs (advanced level) at SUNY Brockport are accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).
column99: Amounts range from $500 to $7,000 stipend + tuition waiver

column2: Master of Science in Education in Adolescence Education: Chemistry
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column47: The Master of Science in Education in Adolescence Education is intended for students who have completed an undergraduate major in the area in which they seek certification. We offer certification in the following content areas: Biology, Chemistry, Earth Science, English, French, Mathematics, Physics, Social Studies, and Spanish. Completion of this program leads to a master's degree and initial and professional New York State teacher certification in Adolescence Education (grades 7-12) in the student's area of concentration. The program prepares teachers to meet the needs of a diverse student population and promotes the development of critically reflective practitioners who are student advocates.
column50: All teacher education programs are accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).
column99: Stipends up to $10,000 and/or tuition waivers
column100: Full tuition waiver available for specific fellowships

column2: Adolescence Education: Chemistry + Students with Disabilities Certification (Advanced Certificate)
column38: School of Education, Health and Human Services
column47: The Adolescence Inclusive Generalist Education with Students with Disabilities program prepares candidates to teach in secondary schools (grades 7-12). Our program provides initial teacher certification for those with a bachelor’s degree in one of the following content areas: English, French, social studies, Spanish, biology, chemistry, earth science, mathematics, or physics. The program is designed for students who do not hold a teaching certificate. Candidates will complete the program as a cohort, taking courses that are carefully sequenced to build on one another, and are tied to two semester-long field experiences. You'll work closely with expert faculty in a supportive, student-centered environment. Upon completion of the program, candidates are eligible for both an initial teaching certificate in their content area and in teaching students with disabilities (generalist).
column50: The School of Education, Health and Human Services at SUNY Brockport is accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).

column2: Master of Science in Education in Adolescence Education: Chemistry + Students with Disabilities Certification
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column47: The Inclusive Adolescence Education program leads to a Master of Science in Education (MSEd) and recommendation for Initial and Professional New York State teacher certification in both Adolescence Education (Grades 7-12) and Teaching Students with Disabilities (Grades 7-12) in a specific content area. This program is a 45-48 credit program designed for candidates who have a bachelor’s degree in one of the content areas in which we offer certification, or the equivalent in coursework.
column50: The School of Education, Health, and Human Services at SUNY Brockport is accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP) and the Association for Advancing Quality in Educator Preparation (AAQEP).
column99: Awards range from $1,000 per year to full tuition scholarships with stipends.

column2: Master of Science in Education in Adolescence Education: Earth Science
column38: Department of Education and Human Development
column47: Our Master of Science in Education in Adolescence Education: Earth Science is for students who have a bachelor’s degree in geology or a related field and are seeking an initial teaching certificate. Our program is nationally recognized by the National Science Teachers Association (NSTA).
column50: All teacher certification programs at SUNY Brockport are accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP). The Adolescence Education - Science Education program, which includes Earth Science, is nationally recognized by the National Science Teachers Association (NSTA).
column99: Up to full tuition; awards starting at $1,000

column2: Master of Science in Education in Adolescence Education: Earth Science + Students with Disabilities Certification
column38: School of Education, Health and Human Services
column39: $709 per semester (Mandatory fees including College, Student Activity, Health, Technology, and Athletic fees)
column47:
SUNY Brockport offers a Master of Science in Education in Adolescence Education that leads to Initial and Professional New York State teacher certification in one of seven content areas for grades 7-12. All of our adolescence education programs lead to dual certification in your chosen content area and students with disabilities.

This is a 45-48 credit hour program designed for students who have an undergraduate degree in the content area they wish to teach, but lack a background in education. It is an intensive, field-based program that immerses students in a school setting from the very first semester. Students complete coursework that provides them with the tools and resources they need to serve all students, including those with special needs.

There is no GRE requirement for this program.
column50: The Teacher Education Unit at SUNY Brockport is accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).
column99: Varies by award (e.g., $1,000, partial or full tuition waivers)

column2: Adolescence Education: Earth Science + Students with Disabilities Certification (Advanced Certificate)
column16: A bachelor’s degree from an accredited US institution or the international equivalent with a minimum 3.0 cumulative GPA. Qualifying degrees and/or coursework in one of the approved content areas. Application form and fee. Official transcripts from all previously attended institutions. Two letters of recommendation. A 500-word statement explaining your reasons for wanting to enter the teaching profession and this program in particular. A current resume. An on-campus or virtual interview may be required.
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column47: The Adolescence Inclusive Generalist Program leads to an initial and professional New York State teaching certificate in the candidate's content area (grades 7-12) and teaching students with disabilities at the same level (generalist). The program is nationally recognized by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP). The program offers a master's degree, an advanced certificate, or a combined master's/advanced certificate program. Coursework focuses on adolescent development and learning, curriculum and instruction in the content area, and adapting instruction for all learners, including those with disabilities.
column50: The program is nationally recognized by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).

column2: Master of Science in Education in Adolescence Education: English
column16:
To be considered for admission, applicants must have:

A bachelor’s degree in English from an accredited US institution or the international equivalent.
A minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0.
A completed application that includes:
Official transcripts from all colleges/universities attended.
One letter of recommendation that addresses the applicant’s potential for success in the teaching profession and in graduate study.
A statement of objectives that addresses how the applicant’s academic background and experience have prepared them for this program and for a career in teaching English.
A writing sample that demonstrates the applicant’s skill in literary analysis.
A resume
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column47:
Become a teacher who is qualified to teach all learners in grades 7-12. Our master’s program leads to dual certification in your content area and in teaching students with disabilities.

The Adolescence Inclusive Generalist Program leads to a Master of Science in Education and prepares teacher candidates to work with students in grades 7-12, including students with disabilities. The program leads to Initial and Professional New York State teacher certification in a content area (grades 7-12) and in Teaching Students with Disabilities (grades 7-12 Generalist).
column50: The Teacher Education programs at SUNY Brockport are accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).
column99: $500 to $7,500 + tuition waiver

column2: Adolescence Education: English + Students with Disabilities Certification (Advanced Certificate)
column16:
To be admitted into our adolescence inclusive generalist teacher certification programs, you will need the following:

- Completed online application
- Baccalaureate degree from an accredited institution
- A minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0
- Transcripts from all previously attended colleges and universities
- Two letters of recommendation
- A statement of objectives
- A resume
- Proof of NYS Initial Teacher Certification in English Language Arts (7-12) is required for the Advanced Certificate.
- Proof of fingerprint clearance is required.
column38: School of Education, Health and Human Services
column47: This program is designed for candidates who already hold an initial and/or professional teaching certificate in English (grades 7-12) and want to become certified to teach students with disabilities at the same grade level. It combines online and on-campus courses, making it an excellent option for working professionals. Through this program, you will develop a deep understanding of disabilities and their effect on learning. You’ll learn how to develop appropriate Individualized Education Programs (IEPs), adapt curricula, and assess student learning. We’ll also prepare you to create a safe, supportive classroom where you can effectively partner with families and other school professionals.
column50: All of our teacher preparation programs are accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).
column99: Up to full in-state tuition and a $10,000 stipend

column2: Master of Science in Education in Adolescence Education: English + Students with Disabilities Certification
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column39: $5,655 per semester (NY State Resident), $10,080 per semester (Out-of-State)
column40: $5,655 per semester (NY State Resident), $10,080 per semester (Out-of-State)
column47: Our dual-certification master’s degree program prepares graduates to become effective English teachers for all students in grades 7-12, including those with disabilities. The program offers a unique focus on young adult literature, the teaching of writing, and literacy in the disciplines. Graduates of this program are well prepared to meet the demands of teaching the diverse population of students in today’s schools. You will earn a Master of Science in Education (MSEd) and be eligible for both initial and professional NYS certifications in English Language Arts (7-12) and Students with Disabilities (7-12 Generalist). This program provides both the master’s degree and the teacher certifications needed by most public school districts. The required coursework can be completed on a full-time or part-time basis, through a combination of on-campus and online coursework. We offer all required courses on a rotating schedule that makes it easy to plan your program of study. As a student in our program, you will benefit from individualized advisement and a variety of field experiences in diverse settings.
column50: All of our educator preparation programs are accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).
column99: Stipends up to $15,000 and/or full tuition scholarships are available through certain fellowships and assistantships.

column2: Master of Science in Education in Adolescence Education: Mathematics
column16: Completed online application, which includes: Official transcripts from all undergraduate/graduate institutions attended, showing a minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0; One letter of recommendation (academic or professional); A statement of objectives; Resume. Initial Teacher Certification in the same area as the certification sought is required for Track 2. Content Core Requirements: Applicants need 30 credits in their content area (i.e. Biology, Chemistry, Earth Science, English, French, Math, Physics, Social Studies, Spanish) with a minimum 3.0 GPA in the content area coursework.
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column47: The Master of Science in Education in Adolescence Education is a 42-45 credit program for students who have a bachelor's degree in a content area, but are not certified to teach. The adolescence program prepares students to teach in grades 7-12. As a student in our program, you will develop the professional knowledge, skills and dispositions necessary to become a highly qualified teacher and educational leader. The program leads to Initial and Professional New York State teacher certification in one of the following content areas: English, social studies, mathematics, biology, chemistry, earth science, or physics.
column50: All of our teacher education programs are accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).

column2: Adolescence Education: Mathematics + Students with Disabilities Certification (Advanced Certificate)
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column47: The Advanced Certificate in Adolescence Education: Mathematics + Students with Disabilities is for students who are already certified in Mathematics 7-12, but who are also seeking Students with Disabilities 7-12 Generalist certification. As a student in this program, you will complete 15 credits of coursework designed to meet the academic requirements for initial/professional certification in Students with Disabilities 7-1_ Generalist. Coursework is aligned with both New York State requirements for certification and Council for Exceptional Children (CEC) standards for teacher preparation. The program is fully online, with synchronous courses that are offered in the late afternoon/evening.
column50: The Division of Education and Human Development at SUNY Brockport is accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP), 1140 19th St NW, Suite 400, Washington, DC 20036, (202) 223-0077.
column99: $1,500 - $10,000 + full tuition scholarship

column2: Master of Science in Education in Adolescence Education: Mathematics + Students with Disabilities Certification
column16: Completed online application, including: Application fee. Official transcripts from all accredited colleges or universities attended. Two letters of recommendation (one must be from a faculty member and one must be from a supervisor). A statement of objectives that explains how the program relates to the applicant’s personal and professional goals. A current resume. Meet the requirements listed under Option I, II, or III below. OPTION I - To be unconditionally accepted into the program, applicants must have a minimum cumulative GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale. OPTION II - Applicants with a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.75 - 2.99 on a 4.0 scale will be considered for admission based on a minimum score on the Graduate Record Examination (GRE): Verbal 147; Quantitative 147; Analytical Writing 3.0. OPTION III - Applicants with a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.5 - 2.74 on a 4.0 scale will be considered for admission based on a minimum score on the Graduate Record Examination (GRE): Verbal 150; Quantitative 150; Analytical Writing 3.5. Note: Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the GRE requirement is currently being waived. In addition, all applicants must have successfully completed: A major in Mathematics with a minimum of 30 credit hours in mathematics coursework, 12 of which must be at the 300-level or above. The coursework should include courses in calculus, linear algebra, geometry, abstract algebra, statistics/probability, and the history of mathematics.
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column47: The Adolescence Inclusive Generalist Program is for candidates who have completed an undergraduate degree in an approved content area and want to become a certified teacher. The program leads to a Master of Science in Education (MSEd) and dual initial teaching certification in a specific content area (grades 7-12) and in Teaching Students with Disabilities (grades 7-12).
column50: All teacher education programs at SUNY Brockport are accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).
column99: The PRODiG Fellowship provides financial support of $20,000 in year one and $10,000 in year two.

column2: Master of Science in Education in Adolescence Education: Physics
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column47: The Adolescence Education: Physics program is a master’s level program that leads to New York State teacher certification in physics (grades 7-12). Our program includes a comprehensive foundation in the teaching of science combined with extensive field experience to prepare you to enter the teaching profession and succeed in your classroom.
column50: All teacher certification programs at SUNY Brockport are accredited by the Association for Advancing Quality in Educator Preparation (AAQEP).
column99: Amounts vary, for example, the Graduate Scholars Program offers $1,500 for the academic year and the Diversity Fellowship provides a full tuition waiver plus a stipend.

column2: Adolescence Education: Physics + Students with Disabilities Certification (Advanced Certificate)
column16:
Applicants for the advanced certificate in adolescence special education must meet the general requirements for admission to graduate study at SUNY Brockport and the following program-specific requirements:
- Possession of a master’s degree from an accredited US institution or its equivalent
- An undergraduate and graduate GPA of 3.0 or higher
- Possession of New York State initial or professional teacher certification in an adolescence education (grades 7-12) content area
- A statement of objectives for pursuing this advanced certificate
- Two letters of recommendation
column38: School of Education, Health, and Human Services
column47: The Adolescence Inclusive Generalist Program leads to a recommendation for an additional teaching certificate in Students with Disabilities 7-12 Generalist. Candidates must already possess an initial or professional certificate in an adolescence content area in order to be admitted into this program. Through this program, you will gain the knowledge and skills to successfully teach all students in the inclusive classroom. You will learn to collaborate and co-teach with other professionals as you work in our partner schools. This program also fulfills the master’s degree requirement for professional certification.
column50: SUNY Brockport’s Department of Education and Human Development is accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).

column2: Master of Science in Education in Adolescence Education: Physics + Students with Disabilities Certification
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column47: Become a more marketable teacher. Our Master of Science in Education in Adolescence Inclusive Generalist Education is a dual-certification program. This program prepares you to become an inclusive educator, certified to teach a content area in grades 7-12 AND certified to teach students with disabilities in grades 7-12. The program can be completed in as little as three semesters. It includes a full year of residency, where you will teach alongside a mentor in a local school. It offers you the opportunity to work and build relationships with a diverse group of students in an inclusive school setting. You will also have the opportunity to participate in our international professional semester programs in England, New Zealand and Australia.
column50: The Teacher Education programs at SUNY Brockport are accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).
column99: Up to $10,000 stipend plus full tuition scholarship (e.g., Diversity Fellowship)

column2: Master of Science in Education in Adolescence Education: Social Studies
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column47: SUNY Brockport offers Master of Science in Education (MSEd) degrees that lead to Initial and/or Professional New York State teacher certification in Adolescence Education (grades 7-12). These programs are for individuals who have a bachelor’s degree in the content area they wish to teach, or the equivalent (see content core requirements). Our Adolescence Education programs include a combination of coursework in pedagogy (the art and science of teaching) and a variety of field experiences in local schools. We offer programs in: Biology, Chemistry, Earth Science, English, Mathematics, Physics, Social Studies, Spanish, French.
column50: All teacher education programs at SUNY Brockport are accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).
column99: Awards include full in-state tuition scholarships and stipends ranging from $7,500 to $15,000.

column2: Adolescence Education: Social Studies + Students with Disabilities Certification (Advanced Certificate)
column16:
In addition to the graduate admission requirements, applicants must also submit the following:

*   Have a master’s degree from an accredited US institution or the equivalent from a foreign institution.
*   A minimum cumulative GPA of 3.0.
*   One copy of all undergraduate and graduate transcripts.
*   A copy of your initial/professional New York State teaching certificate in social studies, 7-12.
*   Statement of Objectives that addresses how this program relates to your professional goals (1-2 pages).
*   Resume.
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column47: This program is designed for students who already have an initial certification in Social Studies 7-12 and a master's degree. Students will take courses to obtain an additional certification in Students with Disabilities 7-12. As a nationally-accredited program, our graduates are highly sought-after. Most are employed as special education teachers in public schools and bring a wealth of expertise to the field. Our graduates can also teach social studies in a special class setting in public schools. Students may pursue this program on a part-time or full-time basis.
column50: All teacher education programs at SUNY Brockport are accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).
column99: Up to full tuition waiver and $10,000 stipend (Graduate Diversity Fellowship) or $1,000 (Promoting Excellence in Graduate Studies Scholarship)

column2: Master of Science in Education in Adolescence Education: Social Studies + Students with Disabilities Certification
column16: Completed online Graduate Application; Bachelor’s degree in history or a related field from a regionally accredited US institution or a comparable degree from an international institution; A minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0 (on a 4.0 scale); Two letters of recommendation submitted online; A statement of objectives; Official transcripts from all accredited colleges or universities attended.
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column46: Social Studies + Students with Disabilities Certification
column47: The Adolescence Inclusive Generalist Program leads to a Master of Science in Education (MSEd) and recommendation for NYS initial and professional teacher certification in both an adolescence content area (grades 7-12) and in teaching students with disabilities at the same grade level. This program is for candidates who have completed an undergraduate major in the content area for which they are seeking certification, but do not yet hold a teacher certification. The program is designed to prepare teachers to work with a broad range of students, including those with disabilities, in grades 7-12 classrooms. This 45-48 credit program can be completed in four semesters of full-time study. Part-time options are also available.
column50: The Teacher Education programs at SUNY Brockport are accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).
column99: Varies (e.g., $1,000 award, or full tuition waiver plus stipend)
column101: Fellowships, Assistantships, Diversity-based scholarships, Need-based grants

column2: Aging Studies (Advanced Certificate)
column16: To be considered for admission, a candidate must have a baccalaureate degree from an accredited institution. Although there are no particular undergraduate prerequisites, it is helpful to have some background in a human service field such as social work, nursing, health science, recreation and leisure studies or psychology. Candidates apply for admission to the Advanced Certificate in Aging Studies through the Graduate School. Requirements include a completed application form, official transcripts from all undergraduate and graduate institutions attended, and two letters of recommendation. In addition, candidates must submit a statement of objectives that specifies their interest in aging studies and how this certificate would help meet their career goals.
column38: School of Arts & Sciences
column47: Our Advanced Certificate in Aging Studies program enhances the knowledge and skills of individuals from various disciplines and professions. The program is specifically designed to provide specialized academic training in gerontology for graduate students and practitioners in the field of aging who wish to become more knowledgeable about the aging process and the needs of older people. This flexible, 15-credit graduate-level program may be taken separately or with a graduate degree program in another discipline. Courses are open to both matriculated and non-matriculated students.

column2: Master of Science in Athletic Administration
column16: To be considered for admission, applicants must submit the following to the Graduate School: Baccalaureate degree from an accredited institution. A minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0. Official transcripts from all colleges/universities attended. Statement of Objectives. A professional résumé. Three letters of recommendation.
column38: School of Arts & Sciences
column47: The Master of Science in Athletic Administration is a 36-credit, fully online program that will prepare you for a successful career in the exciting and competitive world of sports. Whether you are a current or aspiring athletic administrator, coach, or sports professional, our program will equip you with the skills and knowledge you need to lead and manage athletic programs at all levels, from interscholastic to intercollegiate. Our program is designed to provide you with the essential skills and knowledge needed to excel in the dynamic field of athletic administration. You will learn to: Lead and manage athletic programs effectively. Develop and implement strategic plans for athletic departments. Manage budgets and financial resources. Ensure compliance with legal and ethical standards in athletics. Promote a positive and inclusive culture within athletic programs. Market and promote athletic programs to various stakeholders.

column2: Master of Science in Athletic Training
column38: School of Arts & Sciences
column47: The Master of Science in Athletic Training (MSAT) is a 54-credit, two-year full-time cohort program that prepares students to become highly skilled and competent athletic trainers. The program emphasizes the promotion of life-long learning and an evidence-based practice approach to clinical decision making. Students will gain valuable clinical experience under the direct supervision of a certified and licensed athletic trainer and/or physician. Upon completion of the program, students will be eligible to sit for the Board of Certification, Inc. (BOC) examination.
column50: SUNY Brockport is currently accredited by the Commission on Accreditation of Athletic Training Education (CAATE), 2001 K Street NW, Third Floor – North, Washington, DC 20006 USA. The program has chosen to voluntarily withdraw its CAATE accreditation effective August 18, 2023 and is no longer accepting new students.

column2: Bilingual Education (Advanced Certificate)
column16: Students must have a bachelor’s degree from an accredited US institution or the international equivalent with a minimum 3.0 GPA. Students with an undergraduate GPA below 3.0 may be considered for conditional admission. Required Application Materials: Graduate application with fee, Official transcripts from all colleges/universities attended, Initial or Professional NYS teacher certification, A score on the ACTFL Oral Proficiency Interview (OPI) or the NYSTCE Bilingual Education Assessment (BEA) may be required.
column38: School of Education, Health and Human Services
column47: The Bilingual Education Advanced Certificate program provides certified teachers the opportunity to obtain a bilingual extension to their current NYS teaching certificate. Candidates will develop a strong foundation in the theory and practice of bilingual education in order to effectively meet the needs of bilingual learners in a variety of program models. Through a combination of coursework and field experiences, candidates will be prepared to implement culturally and linguistically sustaining pedagogies in their content area, to build partnerships with families and communities, and to serve as leaders and advocates for bilingual learners in all school settings.
column52: $471 for NYS residents, $963 for out-of-state residents

column2: Master of Science in Education in Bilingual Education
column16:
Completed online graduate application
Bachelor’s degree from an accredited college or university
Minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0
One official transcript from all colleges/universities attended
Proof of valid New York State teacher certification in one of the following areas: Childhood Education (1-6), Early Childhood Education (B-2), Adolescence Education (7-12) any content area, Literacy (B-6 or 5-12), Special Education, or TESOL
Written statement of objectives
Two letters of recommendation
Demonstrated proficiency in a language other than English (details in the Graduate Catalog)
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column47: The Bilingual Education master’s program is a 30-36 credit program that prepares certified teachers to work with bilingual students in a variety of settings. The program also leads to eligibility for New York State certification in Bilingual Education.
column99: Varies by scholarship, examples include awards of $500, $1,000, $2,500, or tuition waivers plus stipends.

column2: Master of Business Administration
column38: School of Business
column39: NY State Resident (12+ credits): $5,655/semester; Out-of-State (12+ credits): $11,550/semester
column40: NY State Resident (12+ credits): $5,655/semester; Out-of-State (12+ credits): $11,550/semester
column47: A Master of Business Administration (MBA) is one of the most prestigious and sought after postgraduate degrees in the world. An MBA can benefit professionals in a variety of fields, including management, marketing, finance, and accounting. A SUNY Brockport MBA offers you a quality education and a strong return on your investment. We prepare our students for successful careers in business, non-profit, and government organizations. Flexible, personalized, and affordable. Take classes online or on campus. You choose which option is best for you on a class-by-class basis. Attend full- or part-time. Personalize your degree by selecting elective courses that match your career goals. Take advantage of our extensive alumni network, internship opportunities, and career services. All of this at an affordable SUNY price.
column50: The School of Business is accredited by AACSB International, The Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business. Less than five percent of business schools worldwide have earned this distinction.
column99: Up to $2,500

column2: Master of Science in Chemistry
column11: August 1 for fall admission; December 1 for spring admission
column16:
To apply for admission to the Master of Science degree in chemistry, students must submit the following materials to the Graduate School:

1. An application for graduate admission.
2. Official transcripts of all undergraduate and graduate coursework. A bachelor's degree in chemistry or a closely related discipline from an accredited institution is required, with an overall undergraduate GPA of at least 2.75.
3. Two letters of recommendation from individuals in a position to judge the applicant's potential for graduate study in chemistry.
4. A personal statement describing the applicant’s interest in chemistry and professional goals.
5. An interview with the Graduate Program Director may be required.
column38: School of Arts & Sciences
column47: The Master of Science in chemistry program is a research-based program designed to enhance the skills of the baccalaureate chemist, or to provide a basis for further study at the doctoral level. The program is flexible enough to allow students to concentrate in a sub-discipline in which they are most interested. All students are required to conduct original laboratory research in conjunction with one of the department’s research groups and to complete a written thesis.
column99: Up to $1,500 for scholarships; fellowships can include a $10,000 stipend and full tuition waiver.

column2: Master of Science in Education in Childhood Inclusive Education
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column47: Our Master of Science in Education in Childhood Inclusive Education is a 30-credit program that prepares you to meet the needs of a wide range of students in today's diverse classrooms. This program is for students who already hold an initial certification in childhood education (grades 1-6) and are looking for a master's degree that can lead to a professional certification in both childhood education and students with disabilities (grades 1-6). The program of study includes classes focusing on the unique needs of children with disabilities, literacy instruction, and research.

column2: Master of Science in College Student Affairs & Development
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column39: $5,655 per semester (NY State Resident); $11,550 per semester (Out-of-State)
column40: $5,655 per semester (NY State Resident); $11,550 per semester (Out-of-State)
column47: The Master of Science degree in college student affairs and development provides an opportunity for students interested in working in higher education to receive a professional education. The program’s mission is to educate professionals who are committed to creating systems that are accessible and equitable for all students. We use theory-to-practice and cohort-based models to prepare professionals who will engage with college students and challenge systems to bring about positive change. The program meets the academic standards of the Council for the Advancement of Standards in Higher Education (CAS) and aligns with the ACPA/NASPA Professional Competency Areas for Student Affairs Practitioners. This program is offered in a hybrid format. All classes have a combination of in-person and online instruction.
column50: The program meets the academic standards of the Council for the Advancement of Standards in Higher Education (CAS) and aligns with the ACPA/NASPA Professional Competency Areas for Student Affairs Practitioners.
column52: $471 per credit (NY State Resident); $963 per credit (Out-of-State)
column99: Awards of at least $1,000; full or partial tuition scholarships and assistantships with tuition waivers and stipends are also available.

column2: Master of Science in Computing Sciences
column38: School of Arts & Sciences
column47: The Master of Science in Computing Sciences program is designed for individuals who have an undergraduate degree in computer science or a related discipline and wish to deepen their knowledge and skills in this area. Our computing science graduate program provides students with a solid foundation in computer science through in-depth study of theory, software design, development and application of computers in a variety of fields. Students will learn how to: Apply theory to real-world problems. Master new technology. Work in a team. Take on leadership roles.
column101: Diversity Fellowship, Graduate Opportunity Program, Promising Scholar Awards, Graduate Assistantships

column2: Creative Writing (Advanced Certificate)
column38: School of Arts & Sciences
column47: The Certificate of Advanced Study (CAS) in Creative Writing is an 18-credit post-baccalaureate program designed for students who are interested in creating a collection of original creative work while improving their creative writing skills and deepening their knowledge of the literary arts. The CAS in Creative Writing is ideal for students who wish to pursue a Master of Fine Arts in creative writing but may lack the creative writing coursework to be a strong candidate. It is also an excellent option for current teachers who want to strengthen their creative writing pedagogy. Classes are available in a variety of creative writing genres, including creative nonfiction, fiction, and poetry. Other course topics include studies in literary form and theory, as well as creative writing pedagogy.

column2: Doctor of Education in Educational Leadership
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column47: SUNY Brockport’s Doctor of Education (EdD) in Educational Leadership program is designed for practicing and aspiring P-12 school and district leaders. This innovative cohort-based program uses a practitioner-scholar model to develop students’ capacity to improve P-12 schools and districts. The program focuses on instructional leadership for equity, curriculum and instruction, organizational management, community relations, and leadership for social justice. This program is a member of the Carnegie Project on the Education Doctorate (CPED).
column99: Awards range from $250 - $1,000 per year, and some tuition scholarships are available.
column101: Graduate Diversity Fellowship, Promoting Excellence in Graduate Studies Scholarship, Fannie L. Porter Scholarship

column2: Master of Arts in English – Creative Writing
column38: School of Arts & Sciences
column40: $5,655 per semester (NYS Resident); $11,550 per semester (Out-of-State Resident)
column99: $3,500 - $7,000 stipend per year, plus tuition waiver

column2: Master of Arts in English – Literature
column16: A completed online application. Official transcripts from all accredited colleges or universities attended. A bachelor’s degree from an accredited institution. A minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0. A 300- to 500-word statement of objectives. A 10-15 page, typed, double-spaced critical writing sample on a literary topic. Three letters of recommendation. The GRE requirement is currently suspended.
column38: School of Arts & Sciences
column47: The MA in Literature at SUNY Brockport will develop your knowledge of literary history, theory, and criticism, while also honing your skills in close reading and scholarly writing. You’ll be prepared for advanced work in a doctoral program or for a variety of rewarding careers.
column99: Stipend of approximately $8,000 for the academic year and a full tuition waiver.

column2: Master of Science in Environmental Science & Ecology
column38: School of Arts & Sciences
column47: The Master of Science in Environmental Science and Ecology is a research-based program that stresses an individualized, multidisciplinary approach to environmental problem solving. The program encourages students to combine aspects of environmental science, ecology, biology, chemistry, geology, physical science, and other related fields to create a program tailored to their specific interests and career goals. Students have the opportunity to collaborate with a faculty advisor and graduate committee of their choosing to create a unique curriculum and conduct thesis research on a topic of interest.
column99: $1,000 - $10,000 stipend and/or full tuition scholarship
column101: Graduate Diversity Fellowships, Graduate Assistantships, Program-specific scholarships

column2: Master of Healthcare Administration
column16: To be considered for admission, applicants must have: A bachelor’s degree from a regionally accredited US institution (or the equivalent from a foreign institution) with an undergraduate GPA of 3.0 or higher (on a 4.0 scale). Submitted a completed application to the Graduate School. Submitted official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended. Submitted two letters of recommendation from professional or academic references who can attest to their potential for success in a graduate program. Submitted a statement of objectives. Submitted a résumé.
column38: School of Arts & Sciences
column47: The Master of Healthcare Administration (MHA) program at SUNY Brockport prepares students for management and leadership careers in a wide range of healthcare settings, including hospitals, long-term care facilities, clinics, and community-based health organizations. Students learn to critically examine and evaluate issues and trends in the healthcare system. The curriculum is designed to provide both the breadth and depth of knowledge needed to succeed as a healthcare administrator. Courses emphasize healthcare organization, finance, reimbursement, law and ethics, quality improvement, and human resources. The MHA is a practice-based, professional degree. Students will apply classroom theory to the real-world in a culminating administrative internship in a healthcare organization of interest.

column2: Master of Science in Education in Higher Education Administration
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column47:
The Master of Science in Education in Higher Education Administration at SUNY Brockport is designed for individuals who seek or hold professional positions in administration and student support services at colleges and universities.

Our curriculum is aligned with the student affair standards established by the Council for the Advancement of Standards in Higher Education (CAS) and the American College Personnel Association (ACPA)/National Association of Student Personnel Administrators (NASPA). Students are taught by full-time faculty and student affairs administrators with extensive experience in the field.

Students are required to complete a minimum of one internship (3 credit hours) in an approved higher education setting. Those with limited or no prior higher education experience must complete two internships. In addition, there are many opportunities for volunteering, research, and professional development.

Students may also elect to complete a thesis on a higher education topic of interest, under the guidance of a faculty member.
column99: Specific fellowships offer a stipend of at least $15,000 and a full tuition scholarship.

column2: Master of Arts in History
column38: School of Arts & Sciences
column47: The Master of Arts in History at SUNY Brockport offers students advanced training in historical study. Students in the program develop sophisticated research, writing, and analytical skills and expand their historical knowledge through coursework and independent study. The program prepares students for a variety of careers in fields such as secondary and post-secondary education, public history, and government service, as well as for further study in doctoral programs. The History M.A. program requires 30 credits of graduate work, including 24 credits of coursework and 6 credits dedicated to researching and writing a master’s thesis.
column99: $7,000 stipend plus full tuition waiver for up to 18 credits

column2: Master of Science in Instructional Design
column38: School of Education, Health, and Human Services
column47: The MSEd in Instructional Design prepares students for a wide variety of exciting careers in all sectors (corporate, non-profit, K-12, and higher education). Instructional designers create a wide variety of learning solutions. Our program prepares instructional designers to work in the ever-changing and fast-paced world of learning and performance improvement by grounding them in the foundational theories and allowing them to create a wide variety of learning experiences, from mobile learning to virtual reality.
column99: Awards from $500 up to $5,000 plus tuition waivers are available.

column2: Instructional Design (Advanced Certificate)
column16: To be considered for admission, applicants must meet the following requirements: A bachelor’s degree from an accredited US institution or the international equivalent. An undergraduate GPA of 3.0 or higher is preferred. We will review applicants with a GPA below a 3.0 for provisional admission. Official transcripts from all previously attended colleges and universities. A current resume. A statement of objectives explaining why you are pursuing this certificate. Names and email addresses of three references who can attest to your academic and/or professional capabilities. International applicants are required to have a minimum TOEFL score of 550 paper-based or 79-80 internet-based; IELTS score of 6.5; or Duolingo score of 115.
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column47: This 12-credit, fully online Advanced Certificate in Instructional Design at SUNY Brockport prepares students to design, develop, implement, and evaluate effective and engaging learning experiences. The certificate can be completed as a stand-alone program or taken as part of a master’s degree in Education. This certificate provides educators, instructional designers, and training specialists with the cutting-edge skills and knowledge required to design effective and engaging learning for K-12, higher education, and corporate/non-profit settings. Students will learn the essentials of instructional design, multimedia design and development, and project management. The program is built around the core competencies of the profession, including theoretical and practical foundations, planning and analysis, design and development, implementation and management, and evaluation and assessment.

column2: Master of Arts in Liberal Studies
column38: School of Arts & Sciences
column47: The Master of Arts in Liberal Studies program is a graduate liberal studies program that allows students to study across the disciplines in the humanities, arts, natural sciences, and social sciences. It is an interdisciplinary program designed to meet the special needs and interests of individual students. The program provides a broad, interdisciplinary course of study for students who want to continue their education at the graduate level for intellectual enrichment, career advancement, or preparation for doctoral work.
column99: $10,000 to $15,000 stipend and a full tuition scholarship for the Diversity Fellowship

column2: Master of Science in Education in Literacy Education Program
column16: Completed online application and paid fee. Bachelor's degree from an accredited college or university. Minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0. Official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended. Two letters of recommendation. New York State initial or professional teaching certification. Statement of objectives. Résumé. For applicants with an undergraduate GPA between 2.5 and 2.99, an additional writing sample is required. Please discuss a contemporary issue in the field of education. The issue should be supported by at least three current, professional sources.
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column47: The Master of Science in Education in Literacy Education is for candidates who currently hold a teaching certificate and are seeking to further their knowledge in the field of literacy. Our graduates become literacy leaders in their schools and districts, literacy coaches, and classroom teachers with specialized knowledge in literacy. We offer three different tracks to meet the needs of our diverse graduate students: B-6, 5-12, and B-12. Each program is 30-credits and is offered fully online.
column50: The literacy education graduate programs are accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).
column99: The Graduate Diversity Fellowship provides a full tuition scholarship and a $10,000 stipend.

column2: Local Government Management (Advanced Certificate)
column16:
Students applying for the Advanced Certificate in Local Government Management must have earned a bachelor’s degree from an accredited institution.

Application requires:
- Online application
- Official transcripts from all higher education institutions attended
- Two letters of recommendation
- A statement of objectives that addresses the applicant’s interest in the program and career goals
- Résumé
column38: School of Business
column47:
The Advanced Certificate in Local Government Management provides current and aspiring local government managers with the knowledge and skills necessary for a successful career as a public manager. Students will learn the fundamental skills of municipal management from expert faculty and practitioners in the field.

The Advanced Certificate program is ideal for part-time students who are currently employed by a local government and wish to take the next step in their careers. It can be completed in as little as 12 months. All courses are available in-person or online, providing maximum flexibility for working professionals. Full-time students can supplement their MPA or other graduate degrees with an Advanced Certificate, which allows students to develop specialized knowledge and skills that complement a graduate degree.
column99: Up to full-tuition scholarship and a stipend of $7,500-$10,000 for specific fellowships.

column2: Master of Science in Mental Health Counseling
column16:
A bachelor’s degree from an accredited college or university
A minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0
Completion of at least 18 credits in the behavioral sciences (e.g., psychology, sociology, anthropology, human development, etc.) with a GPA of 3.0 or higher.
Completion of an undergraduate statistics course with a grade of C or higher.
Three letters of recommendation. It is strongly recommended that letters are from faculty who know your academic work.
A personal statement of 2-3 pages, double-spaced, that addresses your reasons for choosing mental health counseling as a profession.
A current resume.
An interview with program faculty (by invitation).
The GRE is not required.
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column47: The 60-credit hour Master of Science in Clinical Mental Health Counseling program is designed for students who want to become licensed mental health counselors (LMHC). The curriculum gives students all the educational requirements they need to become an LMHC in New York State. The curriculum has a strong focus on practice. All students take three semesters of clinical courses: practicum and a two-semester internship. SUNY Brockport has its own community mental health counseling training clinic that serves as one of our main training sites for our practicum and internship students.
column50: The Council for Accreditation of Counseling and Related Educational Programs (CACREP), a specialized accrediting body recognized by the Council for Higher Education Accreditation (CHEA), has granted accreditation to the Clinical Mental Health Counseling (MS) program at SUNY Brockport.

column2: Certificate of Advanced Study in Mental Health Counseling Bridge
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column40: $5,652 (NYS Resident) or $11,556 (Out-of-State) for the total program
column47: The Certificate of Advanced Study (CAS) in Mental Health Counseling Bridge Program provides the opportunity for individuals who currently have a master’s degree in a related field (e.g., school counseling, rehabilitation counseling, social work, psychology) to complete the coursework required to be eligible for licensure as a mental health counselor in New York State. The Bridge Program requires a minimum of 24 credits. The specific number of credits required for each student is determined by a transcript review and in consultation with a faculty advisor.
column101: Diversity fellowships, Merit-based scholarships, Graduate assistantships

column2: Nonprofit Management (Advanced Certificate)
column16:
An official transcript from the institution that awarded your bachelor’s degree.
Three letters of recommendation.
A personal statement describing why you are interested in nonprofit management.
A current resume.
A writing sample.
column38: School of Arts & Sciences
column40: NYS Resident: $7,065; Out-of-State: $14,445 (for the entire 15-credit program)
column47: The Advanced Certificate in Nonprofit Management is a 15-credit, stand-alone certificate program that provides students with specific knowledge about the nonprofit sector. It also serves as a specialization for students in the Master of Public Administration (MPA) Program. The certificate program is appropriate for individuals currently employed in the nonprofit sector who are seeking additional professional development, for individuals who desire to become employed in the nonprofit sector, and for individuals whose employment requires them to interact with the nonprofit sector (e.g., government employees, board members).

column2: Master of Science in Nursing - Adult Gerontology Primary Care Nurse Practitioner
column38: School of Arts & Sciences
column40: $5,655 per semester (NYS Resident); $11,550 per semester (Out-of-State Resident)
column46: Adult Gerontology Primary Care Nurse Practitioner
column47: The Adult-Gerontology Primary Care Nurse Practitioner program prepares graduates to provide primary care to the entire spectrum of adults, including young adults, adults, and older adults. The primary care NP role includes providing comprehensive and continuous care to patients; this care is characterized by a long-term relationship between the patient and the NP. Primary care includes risk-reduction, health promotion, disease prevention, and the management of acute and chronic illnesses. The program emphasizes the development of expertise in health promotion, clinical assessment, and disease management and is guided by a commitment to the care of vulnerable and diverse populations. Our graduates work in a variety of settings, including primary care offices, long-term care facilities, specialty clinics, and correctional facilities.
column50: The master’s degree program in nursing at SUNY Brockport is accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education, 655 K Street NW, Suite 750, Washington, DC 20001, (202) 887-6791.
column99: Varies (e.g., $1,000, up to $4,500/year, full-tuition)

column2: Doctor of Nursing Practice
column38: School of Nursing
column39: $471 per credit hour (NYS Resident); $963 per credit hour (Out-of-State Resident)
column40: $471 per credit hour (NYS Resident); $963 per credit hour (Out-of-State Resident)
column47: Our Doctor of Nursing Practice (DNP) Program is a practice-focused doctoral program that prepares graduates to practice at the most advanced level of nursing. The program is designed for nurses who have earned a master's degree in nursing in an advanced practice specialty (e.g., nurse practitioner, clinical nurse specialist, nurse anesthetist, or nurse midwife), or in a specialty area of nursing leadership such as administration or informatics. Upon completion of the program, graduates will be able to: Provide leadership for evidence-based practice in a variety of settings. Apply clinical scholarship and analytical methods to improve patient outcomes. Serve as a catalyst for change to meet the health needs of a diverse society in a variety of settings. Advocate for health care policy to improve patient safety and quality of care.
column50: The baccalaureate degree program in nursing, master's degree program in nursing, and Doctor of Nursing Practice program at SUNY Brockport are accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education, 655 K Street NW, Suite 750, Washington, DC 20001, (202) 887-6791.
column52: $471 per credit hour (NYS Resident); $963 per credit hour (Out-of-State Resident)

column2: Certificate of Advanced Study in Nursing - Family Nurse Practitioner
column38: School of Arts & Sciences
column47: The Certificate of Advanced Study (CAS) Family Nurse Practitioner (FNP) post-master’s program is a 33-credit program for registered nurses who hold a master’s degree in nursing and who wish to become an FNP. The program prepares students to provide primary care to individuals and families across the lifespan. The curriculum focuses on health promotion, disease prevention, and the diagnosis and management of common acute and chronic health problems. Upon completion of the program, students will be eligible to take the FNP certification exam.
column50: The baccalaureate degree program in nursing, master's degree program in nursing, and post-graduate APRN certificate program at SUNY Brockport are accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education, 655 K Street NW, Suite 750, Washington, DC 20001, (202) 887-6791.
column99: Up to full tuition scholarship and a $10,000 stipend

column2: Master of Science in Nursing - Family Nurse Practitioner
column38: School of Arts & Sciences
column47: The Master of Science, Family Nurse Practitioner program prepares graduates to provide primary care to individuals and families. The program has a strong emphasis on health promotion and disease prevention. The program is designed to be completed through part-time study to allow students to continue to work as they advance their education. All courses have an online component. Some courses are completely online and some are offered in a hybrid format, with a combination of online and in-person classes. Through our rigorous curriculum and practical training, you will learn to: diagnose and treat acute and chronic health problems, promote health and prevent disease, order and interpret diagnostic tests, prescribe medications and other therapies
column50: The baccalaureate degree program in nursing, master's degree program in nursing, and post-graduate APRN certificate program at SUNY Brockport are accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education, 655 K Street NW, Suite 750, Washington, DC 20001, (202) 887-6791.

column2: Master of Science in Nursing Education
column38: School of Arts & Sciences

column2: Master of Science in Education in Physical Education - Adapted
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services

column2: Master of Science in Education in Physical Education - Athletic Administration
column38: School of Arts & Sciences
column47: The Master of Science in Education in Physical Education is designed for individuals who are interested in advanced study within the field. Students can pursue one of three distinct tracks in our program: athletic administration, adapted physical education, or pedagogy. This track provides students the opportunity to combine their knowledge of physical education with the necessary business skills to become a successful athletic director at the interscholastic or intercollegiate level. The curriculum will prepare students to handle all aspects of an athletic program, including finance, legal issues, and marketing. A culminating experience of either a thesis, synthesis, or internship is required.

column2: Master of Science in Education in Physical Education - Teacher Education Pedagogy
column16: In addition to the general requirements for all graduate applicants, you will also need to submit the following: A bachelor’s degree from an accredited US institution (or its equivalent from a foreign institution). A minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0. Initial certification in Physical Education. Documentation of completion of the New York State Dignity For All Students Act (DASA) Training. Three letters of recommendation. A written statement of objectives. Official college transcripts from all institutions attended.
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column47: The Master of Science in Education (MSEd.) in Physical Education is intended for individuals who have completed an undergraduate physical education degree and hold initial New York State (NYS) certification in physical education. This program of study allows candidates to develop the pedagogical content knowledge necessary to meet the challenges of teaching physical education in the 21st century. The program has been nationally recognized by the Society for Health and Physical Educators (SHAPE America) and leads to professional certification in New York State.
column50: The program has been nationally recognized by the Society for Health and Physical Educators (SHAPE America).
column99: $1,000 - full tuition waiver + $10,000 stipend

column2: Master of Arts in Psychology
column16: To apply for the Master of Arts in Psychology program, you will need: an online graduate application, official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended, three letters of recommendation, a statement of purpose describing your academic and professional background, your career goals, and how the MA program in psychology will help you achieve these goals (approximately 500 words), a resume, and a writing sample that demonstrates your ability to write in a scientific style (e.g., a literature review or a research report). Admission requirements include a baccalaureate degree from an accredited institution, a minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale, and 18 credits in psychology, including statistics and research methods. Applicants are not required to submit GRE scores.
column38: School of Arts & Sciences
column47: Our Master of Arts in Psychology program offers a strong foundation in psychological science. Our students gain the skills necessary to conduct psychological research as well as to apply psychological principles to a variety of settings. We pride ourselves on the collaborative relationships our faculty form with our students. Students have numerous opportunities to collaborate with faculty on research through independent studies and research assistantships. Many students co-author conference presentations and journal articles with faculty. The MA program is a good fit for students who plan to pursue a doctoral degree or who want to work in a research setting. All full-time students are guaranteed a graduate assistantship that includes a stipend and tuition waiver. Our students have had a great deal of success after graduation. Over the past 10 years, over 80% of our graduates who applied to doctoral programs were accepted. Others have gone on to work in a variety of research and human service settings.
column99: $500 to $1,500; Full tuition waivers also available

column2: Master of Public Administration
column16:
In addition to the general requirements for all graduate applicants, applicants to the MPA program must submit:

- A current résumé
- Two letters of recommendation from individuals such as a faculty member or a work supervisor who can speak to the applicant’s potential for graduate study and a career in public or nonprofit service.
- A 500-750 word essay that describes the applicant’s career goals and why an MPA will help achieve them.

Students are expected to have completed with a grade of “C” or better an undergraduate course in American government and a course in statistics.

Conditional admission may be granted to students who have not met these requirements.

Standardized test scores (e.g. GRE) are optional for all applicants.
column38: School of Arts & Sciences
column46: Health Care Management, Public Safety, Nonprofit Management
column47: SUNY Brockport’s Master of Public Administration (MPA) program is dedicated to enriching public and nonprofit life by preparing recent college graduates and mid-career professionals to be competent public managers and thoughtful public servants. Our graduates serve as leaders and managers in local, state, and federal government, as well as nonprofit organizations. Our curriculum is designed with the working professional in mind. The MPA degree is offered in two formats: a traditional on-campus format and a fully online format.
column50: The MPA Program at SUNY Brockport is accredited by the Network of Schools of Public Policy, Affairs, and Administration (NASPAA) Commission on Peer Review and Accreditation and is listed on the Annual Roster of Accredited Programs in conformity with NASPAA standards.

column2: Public Health (Advanced Certificate)
column16: Applicants to the Advanced Certificate in Public Health must meet the following requirements: Completed online graduate application with the application fee; Bachelor's degree from an accredited institution; Official transcripts from all colleges/universities attended; A minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0; Two letters of recommendation; Statement of objectives; Current résumé.
column38: School of Arts & Sciences
column47:
The Advanced Certificate in Public Health is intended to provide graduate-level education in public health for individuals who may be working in or plan to work in public health settings. This program is available 100% online.
Upon completion of the program, students will be able to:
1. Explain public health history, philosophy, and values.
2. Identify the core functions of public health and the 10 Essential Services.
3. Explain the role of quantitative and qualitative methods and sciences in describing and assessing a population’s health.
4. List the major causes and trends of morbidity and mortality in the US or other community.
5. Discuss the science of primary, secondary and tertiary prevention in population health, including health promotion, screening, etc.
6. Explain the critical importance of evidence in advancing public health knowledge.
7. Explain effects of environmental factors on a population’s health.
8. Explain the social, political and economic determinants of health and how they contribute to population health and health inequities.
9. Explain how globalization affects global burdens of disease.
10. Explain an ecological perspective on the connections among human health, animal health and ecosystem health (e.g., One Health).
column99: Awards of $1,000 up to a full tuition scholarship are available.

column2: Master of Public Health
column16: Baccalaureate degree from an accredited college or university with a GPA of 3.0 or higher. Official transcripts from all undergraduate and graduate institutions attended. A current resume. Three letters of recommendation from professional and/or academic references. A 500- to 750-word statement of purpose. The statement of purpose should describe the applicant’s interest in the field of public health, why they are interested in SUNY Brockport’s MPH Program, and their career goals. No GRE requirement. A non-refundable $75 application fee.
column38: School of Health & Human Performance
column47: Our Master of Public Health (MPH) degree will prepare you to be a public health leader. You will learn to address pressing public health issues at the local, state, national, and global levels. This program provides a strong foundation in the core areas of public health, including epidemiology, biostatistics, environmental health, health policy and management, and social and behavioral sciences. You will gain hands-on experience through a required internship, where you will apply your knowledge and skills in a real-world setting. Graduates of our program are well-equipped for careers in a variety of settings, including government agencies, non-profit organizations, and private industry.
column50: The Master of Public Health program at SUNY Brockport is accredited by the Council on Education for Public Health (CEPH).

column2: Certificate of Advanced Study in School Building/District Leader
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column47: The Certificate of Advanced Study (CAS) in Educational Administration is offered in a fully online format and is designed for certified teachers and pupil personnel staff who have a master's degree and at least three years of professional experience. The CAS prepares graduates for New York State certification as a School Building Leader (SBL) and School District Leader (SDL). As a student in the Educational Administration program, you will learn to: lead and manage a school building and a school district; understand the link between theory, research, and the practice of educational leadership; develop skills to create and sustain a school culture and instructional program conducive to student learning and staff professional growth; collaborate with families and community members, responding to diverse community interests and needs and mobilizing community resources; and to act with integrity, fairness, and in an ethical manner.
column50: The Educational Administration program at SUNY Brockport is nationally recognized by the National Council for Accreditation of Teacher Education (NCATE).
column52: $471/credit for NYS residents; $963/credit for out-of-state residents

column2: Certificate of Advanced Study in School Counseling
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column47: The Certificate of Advanced Study (CAS) in School Counseling is a 60-credit program for students who have a master’s degree in a related field and wish to become school counselors. The curriculum meets the academic requirements for provisional/permanent certification as a school counselor in New York State. The curriculum focuses on counseling, human development, and professional practice as it applies to school counseling. The program combines academic study with supervised practical experience in school counseling.
column50: The Counselor Education programs at SUNY Brockport are accredited by the Council for Accreditation of Counseling and Related Educational Programs (CACREP).

column2: Master of Science in Education in School Counseling
column38: School of Education, Health and Human Services
column47: The Master of Science in Education in School Counseling is a 60 credit hour program designed to prepare students for careers as school counselors in P-12 school settings. This program provides students with core knowledge and skills in the areas of human growth and development, social and cultural foundations, helping relationships, group work, career and lifestyle development, appraisal, research and program evaluation, and professional orientation. This program also provides students with the specialized knowledge and skills to become effective school counselors.
column50: SUNY Brockport’s MSEd in School Counseling is a CACREP accredited program.

column2: Master of Science in Education in School District Business Leader
column38: School of Education, Health & Human Services
column47: Our Master of Science in Education in School District Business Leader prepares you to meet the NYS certification requirements for the School District Business Leader (SDBL). The SDBL is the chief financial officer of a school district. As SDBL, you are responsible for a variety of tasks including accounting, finance, and budgeting. This program is available 100% online. Our program is taught by experienced faculty, who have extensive experience in the field. Our program is designed to meet the rigorous demands and ever-changing environment in our school systems. You will learn about: Financial aspects of a school system including accounting, budgeting, state aid, purchasing, and capital projects; Management of all support services including food service, transportation, facilities, and technology; Personnel management, including contract negotiations and contract administration; State and Federal laws and regulations impacting school districts.
column99: Varies by award, with some offering up to full tuition or stipends like $10,000 annually.

column2: Certificate of Advanced Study in School District Business Leader
column16:
To be considered for admission, applicants to the Certificate of Advanced Study in School District Business Leader program must have the following:
- A completed online application
- A non-refundable application fee of $50
- Official transcripts from all accredited institutions of higher education attended, with one showing a master’s degree was conferred with a minimum GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale
- Three letters of recommendation from professional and/or academic sources. Letters must be on official letterhead
- A statement of objectives that explains how this program relates to your professional goals (1-3 pages)
- A current resume detailing all professional experiences
- An interview with the SDBL Program Coordinator
- A copy of your initial or professional New York State teacher or pupil personnel services certification
- A minimum of three years of full-time teaching or pupil personnel services experience in N-12 schools
column38: School of Business
column47: The School District Business Leader (SDBL) Post-Master's Certificate program is a 21-credit program offered in a fully online format designed for students who already possess a master's degree and want to acquire New York State certification as a School District Business Leader. SDBL certification allows an individual to serve as the chief business official in a school district. The program develops the leadership and management skills necessary to effectively lead the business operations of a school district. The curriculum is composed of courses in school finance, school law, human resources and collective bargaining, principles of public school district leadership, and information management, followed by a one-year internship experience.
column50: The SDBL program is registered by the New York State Education Department (NYSED) and is a CAEP accredited program.

column2: Master of Science in Education in School Health Education
column16:
Completed online graduate application.
Official transcript(s) from all accredited colleges and universities attended, with a minimum cumulative GPA of 3.0.
Professional resume.
Three letters of recommendation.
